provenance.note: Apparently inherited by Catherine Blake upon the death of her husband, William Blake, in 1827; by inheritance to Frederick Tatham upon the death of Catherine Blake in 1831; Tatham's brother-in-law George Richmond, sold from Richmond's collection, Christie's, 29 April 1897, lot 147 with 21 other works by Blake as listed in Butlin 77 (£2.10s. to Richard Sisley); his daughter, Mrs. John Richmond; given by Mrs. Richmond to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection) in 1922.

desc.objtitle: Three Figures in a Decorative Border, object 1 (Butlin 220)

objnote.p: Butlin 220 titles this work *Two Figures in a Decorative Border*, but there are clearly three figures pictured in the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a female figure with long curly hair is shown from the waist up and appears to wear some sort of gown. She faces down and left, likely to look at a second figure, very lightly sketched, who sits or reclines lower left. Depicted in less detail than the first, this figure may extend one arm to the ground, where it is braced, and may raise the other horizontally(?). Its legs are extended, at least in part, to the right. Behind and to the right of the central figure is the upper body and head of a hunched over, contracted figure facing right and down. Her(?) long hair and elevated right knee obscure her face. her right arm extends downward. A line on her back suggests that she may be gowned. A decorative scroll-like border surrounds the figures on both sides of the scene.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a female figure with long curly hair is shown from the waist up and appears to wear some sort of gown. Most likely standing, she faces down and left, likely to look at a second figure who reclines lower left. The upward-curving line to the left may suggest her right arm is bent upward.

A lightly sketched figure sits or reclines with head at left in the lower left corner. It may extend one arm to the ground, where it is braced, and may raise the other horizontally(?). Its legs are extended, at least in part, to the right. Other fine pencil lines below and to the left of this figure do not picture a clearly identifiable motif.

Behind and to the right of the central figure is the upper body and head of a hunched over, contracted figure facing right and down. Her(?) long hair and elevated right knee obscure her face. her right arm extends downward. A line on her back suggests that she may be gowned.
A decorative scroll-like border surrounds the pair of figures on both sides and lower right and left.
